newsitem.title: UK: Aussie bonds leave others behind in week -Salomon.
newsitem.headline: Aussie bonds leave others behind in week -Salomon.

text.p: Australian government bonds returned sparkling gains for investors in the latest week, beating all other major debt markets, Salomon Brothers said on Friday.
Salomon's world government bond index showed Aussie debt gained 0.87 percent in local currency terms in the week ended August 22, and a hefty 2.40 percent in U.S. dollar terms.
The index as a whole gained 0.21 percent in local terms but fell 0.08 percent in dollar terms.
A tight Australian 1996/7 budget, set out this week by Treasurer Peter Costello, helped bonds higher, analysts said.
The performance made fellow dollar-bloc countries' efforts look dim. Canadian bonds turned in 0.44 percent in local currency terms while the U.S. returned a meagre 0.07 percent.
European high-yielders fared better, with Sweden and Spain taking second and third place over the week with 0.66 percent and 0.62 percent returns in crown and peseta terms.
But political worries and currency weakness dogged Italian debt, oreventing the market from clocking up any more than a 0.09 percent gain in lira terms.
Japan outclassed other G3 economies in local currency terms with a 0.29 percent gain in yen over the week. But Japan's government bonds lost 0.22 percent in dollar ternms.

In core Europe, Bunds paid out a modest 0.11 percent in marks and fell 0.58 percent in dollar terms while France managed a little better, gaining 0.35 percent for franc investors and losing 0.10 percent for dollar players.

Belgian, Danish and Dutch bonds notched up local currency gains of 0.38, 0.26 and 0.09 percent over the week, while Swiss bonds returned 0.25 percent and the Austrian market fell 0.04 percent on the week.

Salomon's bond index is calculated using all government bonds with over one year to maturity, weighted for market capitalisation. Only bonds freely available to institutional investors and with a certain minimum amount outstanding are included. Returns take account of price moves and accrued interest.
